EQUISTAR Chemical Company

Channelview Operations (CVON)

8280 Sheldon Road

Channelview, TX 77530



Risk Management Plan Executive Summary October 29, 2013



1.0 Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



At the EQUISTAR Channelview Plant (CVON) we are committed to operating and maintaining our processes to protect our employees, the public, and the environment. We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to manage the risk for all stakeholders.  This document provides a brief overview of our comprehensive risk management activities to mitigate and prevent the possibility of an accidental release of a regulated chemical.



It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent the release of a regulated substance.  However, if such a release does occur, our trained emergency response personnel are at hand to control and mitigate the effects of any release. We also coordinate with the Houston Ship Channel Area's Channel Industries Mutual Aid (CIMA) which provides additional emergency response expertise.



The site will restart the Methanol unit which is part of the East/Mid Hydrocarbons process.  Anhydrous ammonia will be utilized for air pollution abatement and will be injected into the combustion exhaust stream of the reformer as part of a selective catalytic reduction process to reduce emissions of nitrogen oxides (NOx).  Anhydrous ammonia will be stored in a pressurized tank in a quantity above the threshold, which prompts this change in the RMP submission.  As part of the overall review of the re-submission, the regulated substances and inventories were reviewed and modifications have been made accordingly.



2.0 Stationary Source and Regulated Substances



Our facility cracks Naphtha, OP-400, and condensates into a number of products that include Propylene, Butadiene, Isoprene, Isobutane and other olefins. In addition, Methyl Tertiary Butyl Ether (MTBE) and an assort

ment of products are produced in the East Plant / Mid Plant unit, including Isopropanol. There are two Olefins Cracking units and one East Plant/Mid Plant manufacturing unit.   These operating units utilize the following chemicals that have been identified by the EPA as having the potential to cause significant off-site consequences in the event of their substantial accidental release: 



Toxics - 



Anhydrous Ammonia:  Approximately 58,000 lbs. of anhydrous ammonia will be stored in a pressurized tank for use in the Methanol unit air pollution abatement equipment and will be injected into the combustion exhaust stream of the reformer as part of a selective catalytic reduction process to reduce emissions of nitrogen oxides (NOx).  



Flammables



1,3-Butadiene:  Approximately 13 million pounds of Butadiene are stored and in process within the East Plant. Butadiene is further utilized on the Poly-Butadiene process within the Mid Plant as well as sold as a finished product.



Butane:  Approximately 1.4 million lbs. are contained in storage and within the East Plant and Olefins units and tank farms. Butane is an intermediate chemical and is sent to the Olefins Cracking Units for further processing.



Ethane:  Approximately 180,000 lbs. are stored and used in the Olefins processes.  It may also be sent to external customers.



Isobutane:  Approximately 3 million lbs. are stored and used in the East Plant.  Isobutane is a feedstock for the Alkylation unit.



Isobutylene: Approximately 1.1 million lbs. are contained in storage and within the East Plant process unit.  Isobutylene is an intermediate chemical used in the production of MTBE.



Isoprene:  Approximately 990,000 lbs. are produced and stored within the East Plant.  Isoprene is sold as finished product.



Propylene:  Approximately 1.5 million lbs. are stored and used on-site. Propylene is refined in the Olefins.



Flammable Mixtures:  Approximately 260 million lbs. of flammable mixtures are stored and u

tilized through-out the Olefins and East/Mid Hydrocarbons units.  These include Naphtha, OP-400, and other condensate feeds stored and used in the Olefins units.   Also included are various hydrocarbon mixtures that are incoming feed stocks and/or intermediate streams for the Olefins and East/Mid Hydrocarbons units.  Regulated substances in these flammable mixtures are:  1,3-Butadiene, Butane, 1-Butene, cis- and trans-2-Butene, Isobutane, Isobutylene, Isopentane, Isoprene, 2-Methyl-1-Butene, 1,3-Pentadinene, Pentane,  1-Pentene, 2-Pentene, Propane, Propylene, and Vinyl Acetylene.



Our accidental release prevention programs and our contingency planning efforts help us effectively manage the hazards that are posed to our employees, the public, and the environment by our use of these chemicals.







3.0 General Accident Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



EQUISTAR Chemicals Channelview Operations (CVON) has taken the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set forth under 40 CFR Part 68. Additionally, this facility was designed and constructed in accordance with strict internal engineering standards and is subject to the requirements under 29 CFR 1910.119 - Process Safety Management.



Process Safety Information: Chemical hazard, process technology, and equipment information is documented, kept up-to-date, and made available to all workers.



Process Hazards Analyses (PHAs): A rigorous practice of reviewing new processes or changes to existing processes at the design stage is utilized, with the overall thought of identifying and mitigating health, safety and environmental issues before installation or operation. Scheduled PHAs are conducted every 5 years to revalidate previous hazard reviews and recommend corrective actions to prevent accidents.



Operating Procedures: Operating procedures provide detail on how to safely operate a process and are kept up-to-date constantly through a review du

ring any operator training opportunity.  They are also reviewed every five years.  Operating procedures are based on process hazard / risk reviews and are periodically modified as a result of management of change activities or after completion of a process PHA. Operating procedures include safe start-up and emergency shutdown of a process unit.



Operator Training / Qualification Program: A training and testing program is in place to ensure that operators have the proper skills and knowledge prior to allowing them to independently operate a process. Operator re-qualification is required at a minimum of every three years.



Maintenance Procedures: Specific procedures for maintaining process equipment are in place to ensure it operates safely. Plant and unit specific procedures for servicing operating equipment are in place, including preventive / predictive maintenance and reliability programs.



Maintenance Training:  Mechanics and other craftsmen who perform routine or complex maintenance tasks are trained and tested on process equipment and inspections on operating equipment to ensure they have the required knowledge and skills.



Mechanical Integrity Program: Vessels (including shipping containers) and other process equipment are periodically tested and inspected to ensure safe operations, following recognized standards and governmental requirements.



Quality Assurance: A system is in place to ensure that purchased equipment and materials meet established engineering standards and specifications.



Process Change Authorizations (Management of Change / PCAs): The site has a management system to ensure that modifications to a process or facilities are evaluated to ensure continued safe operations. Design (DSRs) and Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs) are conducted for facility or process changes prior to implementation of the change.



Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs): Reviews are conducted just prior to startup to ensure that modified facilities or proces

ses are safe to operate.



Incident Investigation:  The site ensures that accidents, incidents, and near misses are properly investigated to determine the root cause as well as contributing causes. In addition to the investigation, action items resulting from the investigation are communicated site-wide and tracked to completion to prevent recurrence.  CVON has not experienced any accidental releases regulated under the RMP rule over the past 5-years.  An incident did occur in the East Plant in May, 2012 when there was a flammable mixture release when a valve body failed.  There were no consequences to the release; however the site requires investigation of incidents that could have resulted in catastrophic consequences.



Compliance Audits: Audits are conducted on a regular basis to verify the provisions set forth under the PSM and RMP rules are being implemented. These audits are conducted at a minimum of every three years.



Employee Participation: The site has a written employee participation plan that defines how employees are consulted in the development and maintenance of the PSM/RMP elements.  Employees participate in PHA's and they have access to the PHA's and other process safety information.   Each operating and maintenance area has a representative on the Plant Safety Committee (EAGLES - Eliminating Accidents Guarantees Lasting Employee Safety) which supports occupational safety activities.  Contractors have a representative on this team.

 

Contractor Safety Program: The plant has a program to ensure that contractors are properly trained, and uses the Houston Area Safety Council as a tool to provide the basic HSE training required of a contractor prior to entering a chemical manufacturing facility. All contractor employees must attend the Houston Area Safety Council training and be certified through examination prior to arriving at the plant. In addition to basic training CVON site specific training is required prior to arriving at the plant.  The c

ompany has a rigorous process for pre-screening all contract companies to ensure they meet all company requirements.  All resident and many non-resident contractors are part of the site's CHESS (Contractors Helping Everyone Stay Safe) Team.



4.0 Five Year Accident History



None.



5.0 Emergency Response



The site maintains an integrated contingency plan, which consolidates all of the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning. This program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  Furthermore, the site coordinates with the community response plan through the North Channel LEPC, as well as the Harris County Office of Emergency Management. The site is also a participating member of the Houston Ship Channel Area Channel Industries Mutual Aid (CIMA).  The site has a severe weather plan to prepare and recover from hurricanes, severe storms/tornadoes and flooding.



6.0 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



The following is a list of improvements planned to be implemented at the facility to help prevent and/or better respond to accidental chemical releases:



?    Continued review and upgrade of safety interlocks system.

?    Revalidate all PHAs in accordance with requirements under RMP and PSM.

?    Revise the emergency response plan after critiques from recent drills.

?    Update facility security following the Security and Vulnerability Survey.

?    Continue to utilize the tools of root cause analysis to investigate incidents and develop effective solutions to prevent recurrence.
